an3.71:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
an3.71:1.2: Then the wanderer Channa went up to Venerable Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.
an3.71:1.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda:
an3.71:1.4: “Reverend Ānanda, do you advocate giving up greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:2.1: “But what drawbacks have you seen, Reverend Ānanda, that you advocate giving up greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:3.1: “A greedy person, overcome by greed, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:3.2: When greed has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:3.3: A greedy person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:3.4: When greed has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:3.5: A greedy person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:3.6: When greed has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:3.7: Greed is a destroyer of sight, vision, and knowledge. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.
an3.71:4.1: A hateful person, overcome by hate, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. …
an3.71:4.2: A deluded person, overcome by delusion, intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:4.3: When delusion has been given up, they don’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both. They don’t experience mental pain and sadness.
an3.71:4.4: A deluded person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:4.5: When delusion has been given up, they don’t do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an3.71:4.6: A deluded person doesn’t truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:4.7: When delusion has been given up, they truly understand what’s for their own good, the good of another, or the good of both.
an3.71:4.8: Delusion is a destroyer of sight, vision, and knowledge; it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.
an3.71:4.9: This is the drawback we’ve seen in greed, hate, and delusion, and this is why we advocate giving them up.”
an3.71:5.1: “But, reverend, is there a path and a practice for giving up that greed, hate, and delusion?”
an3.71:5.2: “There is, reverend, a path and a practice for giving up that greed, hate, and delusion.”
an3.71:5.4: “It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
an3.71:5.5: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
an3.71:5.6: This is the path, this is the practice for giving up that greed, hate, and delusion.”
an3.71:5.7: “This is a fine path, a fine practice, for giving up that greed, hate, and delusion.
an3.71:5.8: Just this much is enough to be diligent.”
